importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The subprime car delinquency rate doubled since 2021, marking a significant economic shift.
The default rate among subprime car borrowers reached nearly 10% in September, signaling worsening financial stress.
Motor vehicle repair costs surged 15% year-over-year, reflecting growing financial strain on car owners.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: A doubling of subprime car delinquency since 2021 indicates a prolonged economic vulnerability in lower-income consumer groups.
A rise in delinquencies and repossessions from 2023 to 2025 reflects worsening financial conditions following pandemic-related economic shifts.

keyTakeAways: The delinquency rate for subprime borrowers (credit scores below 670) on car loans has doubled since 2021, reaching 6.43%, the highest level since the early 1990s.
Car repossessions are at the highest rate since the Great Recession of 2008–2009.
Subprime borrowers face significant financial strain due to record auto payments, rising repair and insurance costs, and prior defaults on mortgages, rent, and student loans.
The delinquency rate for prime borrowers (higher credit scores) remains low at less than 0.5%, highlighting a widening gap between wealthy and lower-income Americans.
This reflects the 'K-shaped economy' where some consumers benefit from stock market gains while others struggle with inflation and rising costs.
Lenders are implementing GPS tracking and ignition disabling in vehicles to facilitate repossession, indicating a surge in repossession activity comparable to the Great Recession.
Elevated repair costs (15% YoY increase) and insurance hikes (5% increase in August) compound financial stress on car owners.

namedEntities.name: Fitch Ratings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fitch Ratings reported that the subprime car delinquency rate has doubled since 2021, providing key data on economic distress.

namedEntities.name: Cox Automotive
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A consumer finance and data analytics company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cox Automotive provided data showing a 10% default rate among subprime car borrowers in September, indicating financial stress.

namedEntities.name: Experian
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major credit reporting and data services company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Experian reported that 46% of used car loans have monthly payments of $500 or more, illustrating the burden of auto financing.

namedEntities.name: Bureau of Labor Statistics
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. government agency that collects labor and economic data
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported a 15% year-over-year surge in vehicle repair costs, highlighting rising ownership costs.

namedEntities.name: Jonathan Smoke
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He emphasized that there is 'no room for error' in the financial situation of subprime borrowers.

namedEntities.name: Rod Chadehumbe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief asset-backed securities strategist at Bloomberg Intelligence
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He noted that prime borrowers are not struggling, highlighting the disparity between economic groups.

namedEntities.name: Pamela Foohey
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Law professor at University of Georgia, expert in auto finance and bankruptcies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She explained that lenders are using GPS tracking and ignition disabling to increase repossession efficiency.

namedEntities.name: George Badeen
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of Midwest Recovery and Adjustment in Detroit and industry trade group leader
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He stated that repo numbers indicate current activity is comparable to the Great Recession, signaling economic instability.

namedEntities.name: subprime borrowers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Credit score group below 670 with higher financial risk
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group faces the highest delinquency and repossession rates, indicating systemic economic hardship.

namedEntities.name: prime borrowers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Credit score group above 670 with lower financial risk
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their low delinquency rate contrasts with subprime borrowers, highlighting economic inequality in the K-shaped economy.

namedEntities.name: Great Recession (2008–2009)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Current car loan delinquency and repossession rates are compared to those periods, signaling similar financial instability.

namedEntities.name: Covid pandemic
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pandemic-era financial relief measures have ended, and delinquency rates are rising again, showing economic fragility post-pandemic.

namedEntities.name: student loans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Student loan payments resumed in 2023, increasing financial pressure on borrowers who now face multiple debt obligations.

namedEntities.name: car payments
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Record high payments due to inflation and interest rates are pushing subprime borrowers into financial distress.

namedEntities.name: auto payments
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Monthly financial obligation for car ownership
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Payments now exceed $500 for half of new and used car loans, making vehicle ownership unaffordable for many.

namedEntities.name: repair costs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Repair costs have surged 15% year-over-year, adding to car ownership burden and financial stress.

namedEntities.name: car insurance
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Insurance rates rose by 5% in August, contributing to overall cost of car ownership.

namedEntities.name: inflation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: General increase in prices across the economy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Inflation has driven up prices for cars, repairs, and insurance, increasing financial strain on consumers.

namedEntities.name: labor market
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A weaker labor market could lead to more layoffs and increased financial hardship for subprime borrowers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A significant rise in car loan delinquency among subprime borrowers—those with credit scores below 670—is signaling deep economic distress in the U.S. The rate has doubled since 2021, reaching 6.43%, and surpasses levels seen during past recessions. This surge is driven by record car prices, high interest rates, rising repair and insurance costs, and the resumption of student loan payments after pandemic pauses. Subprime borrowers face severe financial stress, often having missed payments on other debts, and many are forced into default or repossession. In contrast, prime borrowers with better credit scores remain largely unaffected. The situation reflects a 'K-shaped economy' where wealthier individuals thrive while lower-income consumers struggle. Lenders are now using GPS tracking and ignition disabling to recover vehicles, indicating a level of repossession activity similar to the Great Recession. Economists warn that a weakening labor market could worsen this trend, underscoring a growing divide in economic well-being across the U.S. population.
title: A significant group of Americans are falling behind on their car payments - an economic warning sign
